ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Phased Searching Writeup
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, Thanks for  response on the phased search write-up. Responses below... ... The first question here is,  if I were to make the write-up publication

Hi Ken,

Thanks for  response on the phased search write-up. Responses below...

Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Here are some comments on your writeup.  I think it's great work and 
>very helpful.  It seems from your preliminary results that phased 
>search can significantly outperform complexification alone, so we 
>might now be able to solve even harder problems.  For that reason 
>alone, this is probably publication-worthy work, although there are 
>a few things that should be addressed, or at least I'm curious about:
>  
>
The first question here is,  if I were to make the write-up publication 
worthy what avenues are open with regards to getting work published? 
Placing the work on the internet works well up to a point, but a peer 
reviewed paper has more credability and can be used as a base point for 
further research by others, plus it is something to put in the ole CV :)

>-Why is the phased search so much faster?  It seems to be 5 or 10 
>times faster based on what you say, but that seems more dramatic 
>than I would expect.  I guess it's because this task is all about 
>network activation and has no "domain simulation" involved.  
>
Yeh, because the evaluation code is so simple and fast, something like 
90% (at a guess) of the execution time is spent in the actual NEAT 
process of generating offspring, comparing genomes and decoding genomes 
into working networks. Therefore if you reduce the size of the genomes 
within the population then you can expect a dramatic speed up. There is 
also a scaling issue in SharpNEAT right now that means that it slows 
down a lot more than it should as the genome size increases. There's a 
simple fix but I've not had time to work on SharpNEAT lately.

>That 
>won't be the case in other domains, and therefore the speedup aspect 
>of this might be misleading.  Therefore, it would be helpful to see 
>comparison graphs with generations on the x axis instead of time.  
>Usually people in machine learning are interested in # evaluations 
>to get a soltuion rather than CPU time since ultimately that's the 
>main factor in computational complexity.  Time alone doesn't give 
>that information but generations does.
>  
>
yes I can see the value in showing generation based graphs, with the 
time based graphs the percieved benefit may just be from performing more 
generations in a given amount of time - the none phased search runs may 
have achieved the same result if allowed to run to the same # of 
generations. I still like the time based graphs though because 
ultimately we need to know if we can find solutions within realistic 
time frames. It's not much use devising a technqiue that can solve 
problem X within 1,000 years :)

>-If you ran the complexifying or blended runs for the same number of 
>generations as the phased runs would they catch up?  That's another 
>reason it would be good to see a comparison by generations rather 
>than time.  If they can't catch up in the same # of generations, 
>that is a very strong result!
>  
>
Yes I agree that this would be an interesting experiment to run.

>-To really validate this approach, we need a task that cannot be 
>solved without hidden nodes.  So probably another experiment in a 
>new domain would be a good idea.
>  
>
I'm intending to do some phased search experiments with Tic-Tac-Toe, and 
probably function regression. The later hopefully leading on to some 
form of financial data prediction experiment(s).

>-The # hidden nodes in a soltuion is interesting in its own right.  
>For example, what is actually happening to keep complexity steady: 
>Are connections being added then taken away back and forth over and 
>over, or are several hidden layers being built at the same time as 
>some inputs are being pruned?  A graph of # nodes per solution would 
>give some insight.
>  
>
The search is mainly one of finding connections. Although hidden nodes 
do accumulate during the complexification phase they almost always are 
completely removed by the end of a prune phase. Some  'common feature' 
nodes exist by way of connections from output nodes to other output nodes.


>-It would be interesting to see a picture of a solution network.  It 
>would help address the above point and also it's just fun to see :)
>  
>
Yeh the problem here is that the networks from complexifying and blended 
runs are really complex, whereas the ones that have been pruned have no 
hidden node and frankly look a bit boring :)  One idea is to runt eh 
networks from a complexifying run through a prune phase to prune away 
redundant structure. My guess is that they will be utilising some hidden 
nodes, possibly a lot, whereas the pruning phase nets normally don't 
have any.

Thanks again for the feedback,

Colin.
